channel.title: Simple Updater
channel.description:
This is a simple updater which I created for learning purposes only.
It is probably not needed, but I am releasing the source to this under the GPL license. So, if you release any further updates of this updater, you also must release the source code.
The updater only gets the values for all the RSString fields. Yes, RSString is StringWrapper. I call ti RSString because I honestly don't see how it wraps anything, but if someone can correct me on this, I'd be more than happy to change it.
I have also added simple support for accessor methods. The updater is currently not using it, but if you want to learn some stuff about accessor methods, take a look at it. The general method is there for adding int accessor methods, and it is very easy to change it to add any sort of type.
The updater does download the runescape jar file, and the method to do is so is pretty much the same in every updater. So, if you use it, no needs to give credit to me.
I have heavily commented the project. Infact, I have commented just about every line in the getRSString() method, so as to help you understand what all is going on, and to help you create new methods for new fields.
I included the Run.bat and Run.sh, the shell-script should work, but tell me if there is any problems because I'm not on my linux box and therefore can't test.
If you have any questions, please post here. And feel free to build on to the updater all you wish, for learning purposes or whatever purpose you have.

item.title: Simple Updater
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:24, topic:219929”][quote author=frank_ link=topic=288851.msg2522009#msg2522009 date=1225939218]
if you are going to use xml, at least use it properly
[/quote]
Agreed. It should be value and take advantage of nesting.
rather than: <client_field class=“x” field=“v” type=“boolean” isarecursive=“true”>string.mutable</client_field>
it should be: xvw[/quote]attributes r geyyyy

[quote=“BAsh, post:24, topic:219929”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=288851.msg2521757#msg2521757 date=1225917440]
It’d be a pretty neat idea to write a little program that would read that information and display it, you could even create a nice looking UI.
[/quote]
I think the best way would be html. Screw the gui use the browser. As for parsing it you can use some non-standard attributes that the browser will ignore.[/quote]XSL

Read full topic

item.title: Simple Updater
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

frank_:

if you are going to use xml, at least use it properly

Agreed. It should be value and take advantage of nesting.
rather than: <client_field class=“x” field=“v” type=“boolean” isarecursive=“true”>string.mutable</client_field>
it should be: xvw

Yz85Racer:

It’d be a pretty neat idea to write a little program that would read that information and display it, you could even create a nice looking UI.

I think the best way would be html. Screw the gui use the browser. As for parsing it you can use some non-standard attributes that the browser will ignore.

Read full topic

item.description:

terminal:
done 93 hooks.

file:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<updater_component name=“runescape.string.fields”>

fields in the runescape string class string.data string.length string.hash string.mutable class y possible match class x possible match class x identified field y identified field a skipped field b skipped field z identified field w identified field v identified dumping class

now my question is, WHY make two outputs, use one for both?[/quote]if you are going to use xml, at least use it properly

item.title: Simple Updater
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

Ollie:

now my question is, WHY make two outputs, use one for both?

Mine updater uses settings file to determine what needs to be outputted. Which means not everything is in the dumped file.
Also logging to the screen is just an optional feature, so you can quickly copy paste outputs if you like.
Also my reflection data isn’t in xml format, which makes it even less clear to read ;).

Read full topic

It’d be a pretty neat idea to write a little program that would read that information and display it, you could even create a nice looking UI.

item.title: Simple Updater
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:17, topic:219929”][quote author=qauters link=topic=288851.msg2521334#msg2521334 date=1225879507]
Using bullet points should be used to clear it up really. Something like:

* Class: 'RSString' --> 'ok'
   ^ Field: 'RSString.bytes' --> 'ok.X'
   ^ Field: 'RSString.editable' --> 'ok.S'
   ^ Field: 'RSString.hash' --> 'ok.Z'
   ^ Field: 'RSString.length' --> 'ok.g'

[/quote]
Wouldn’t it make sense to log it to a file, too?[/quote]
Yes, but I use that for my reflection data and that’s a bit less clear to read.

Mine updater contains an option to dump it to screen, in case you want to post your output.

Read full topic

item.title: Simple Updater
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“Epidemic, post:7, topic:219929”]Hey,

I just want say how useful this has been for me. Thanks a lot :). You have answered a lot of questions for me but also given me a lot more questions that need answer :).

Looking at the updater, your using if statements to find the fields. I was wondering how do I find out the properties of other fields so that I can add some more if statements to that updater to find other fields.

I think that is worded correctly :P. If not I probably have a misunderstanding somewhere.[/quote]Look at them through a bytecode viewer like JBE. Take a look here:

moparisthebest.com

moparisthebest.com

programming, irc, cars

Read full topic

item.title: Simple Updater
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“nueb35, post:5, topic:219929”]i mean

URL RS = new URL("jar:http://world37.runescape.com/runescape.jar!/"); RS.openConnection();

but the the one used to actually download is

InputStream in = new URL("http://world37.runescape.com/runescape.jar").openStream();[/quote]Your correct.

Mistake on my part, I meant to remove that.

I was experimenting with the most efficient way to go about doing things, thanks for pointing it out.

Read full topic

[/quote]
